facts.text: Import and export of goods regulated by Imports and Exports Act, 1947; Section 3 empowers Government to issue orders prohibiting, restricting or controlling import/export.

Export Control Order 1968 issued under 1947 Act; Clause 3(1) prohibits export of goods in Schedule 1 without licence; Mica scrap and mica waste item No. 22A Part B Schedule 1 (export allowed on merits or subject to ceilings/conditions).
Trade Notice dated 13 March 1968 (reproducing Export Control Order No.1/68-EIC dated 8 March 1968): Export of mica including splittings, blocks, scrap, waste allowed on merits.

Impugned Trade Notice dated 29 January 1972 by Controller of Imports & Exports: Canalisation of export of all grades/varieties of mica (except manufactured/fabricated mica, micanite, reconstituted mica, mica powder, mica paper) through Minerals and Metals Trading Corporation of India Ltd. (Corporation), effective from 24 January 1972.

Pre-canalisation commitment category in impugned Notice: Export allowed if contract/telegraphic offer-acceptance before 24 January 1972 and irrevocable L/C at sight opened before 24 January 1972 in India/foreign bank; exporters to furnish particulars by 15 February 1972 (quantity, grade, delivery, buyer, contract details, L/C, shipped/balance quantities).

Corporation's Press Notice post-impugned Notice: Procedure for exporters - furnish particulars of foreign buyers; Corporation enters principal-to-principal sale contract with buyer, back-to-back procurement with supplier; buyer opens confirmed irrevocable assignable L/C in Corporation's favour; service charge <=1% FAS value; sales price not less than Govt fixed FAS prices or Mica Export Promotion Council recommendations; post-24 Jan L/Cs to be amended in Corporation's favour.
Petitioner wrote to respondents giving details of nine contracts accepted from overseas buyers prior to 24 January 1972; some shipments made, balance post-24 January 1972.

Several exporters opened L/Cs post-24 January despite notice; Govt issued Export Clarification Circular No.3/1972 dated 17 April 1972: Exports allowed in private parties' names if L/C opened before 31 March 1972 (even if shipment period expired), shipment by 30 June 1972.

Representations from Bihar Mica Exporters Association (25 Jan, 16 March 1972), Mica Chamber of Commerce Gudur (9 Feb 1972): Difficulties due to lack of procedure details - export consignments worth Rs.70 lakhs (Jan), Rs.130 lakhs (Feb), Rs.150 lakhs (Mar), Rs.150 lakhs (Apr-Jun) stuck; non-assignable L/Cs, demurrage risks; sought relief for pre-24 Jan contracts.
Second impugned Trade Notice 20 April 1972: Modified canalisation - shipments allowed up to 30 June 1972 against pre-24 Jan contracts even if L/C not opened before 24 Jan.

Mica export policy (Govt notification 27 June 1966, amended; Export Trade Control Handbook 1970): Shipment based on application, 100% irrevocable L/C; fabricated mica (incl. powder) exempt from 100% L/C stipulation.
State affidavit: Exclusion of mica powder to develop nascent mica powder industry.

legal_issues.text: Whether the canalisation scheme is a valid exercise of power under 1947 Act and 1968 Order, or a scheme to transfer business/goodwill to Corporation outside purview of Act.
Whether the scheme imposes unreasonable restriction violating Article 19(1)(g) (loss of FX, profit, breach suits by buyers).
Whether scheme valid post-emergency under 1947 Act.
Whether scheme violates Article 14 (discrimination: mica powder excluded, allowing conversion of scrap/waste).
Whether fixation of 24 Jan 1972 re L/C opening arbitrary, violating Article 19/14; extension to 31 March mala fide.
Whether 1% service charge is unreasonable restriction/tax violating Article 265.

petitioner_arguments.text: Scheme not canalisation but transfer of business/goodwill to Corporation outside Act.
Unreasonable restriction: loss of FX, profit; buyers can sue for breach.
Discrimination: mica powder excluded, scrap/waste can be converted/exported individually.
24 Jan date re L/C arbitrary, no relation to scheme; extension to 31 March mala fide to benefit influential.

respondent_arguments.text: Scheme pursuant to s.3(1)(a) 1947 Act, cl.6(1) 1968 Order allowing canalisation through specialised agencies.
Canalisation reasonable in public interest, ensures quality/volume; no acquisition of business.
No Art 14 violation: Corporation is State agency, total exclusion no discrimination; mica powder exclusion to develop industry.
24 Jan date rational re L/C to prevent antedating; relaxations to minimise hardship per representations.
1% service charge is quid pro quo by Corporation as licensee, not tax.

court_reasoning.text: Canalisation valid under cl.6(1) 1968 Order; dominant purpose to ensure uniform quality/increase volume via State agency, not acquire business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restriction reasonable; follows Glass Chatons/Devdas precedents.

court_reasoning.text: No Art 19(1)(g) violation: Canalisation per se reasonable in public interest; pre-canalisation concessions mitigate hardship, no self-induced loss if availed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Traders have no vested right post-canalisation.

court_reasoning.text: No issue post-emergency; power under 1947 Act persists.
No Art 14: Total exclusion via canalisation, no competition; mica powder exclusion has intelligible differentia (develop industry).
24 Jan L/C date rational to prevent evasion; contracts subject to export laws/licences; relaxations bona fide per representations to avoid dislocation.
1% charge quid pro quo service by Corporation licensee, not tax; no levy by Govt.

holdings.text: Canalisation scheme valid under 1947 Act/1968 Order; does not violate Arts 14,19(1)(g),265.
Date fixation/extension rational, not mala fide.

precedents_cited.case_name: Devdas of Bhimji Gohil v. Joint Chief Controller of Imports & Exports
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld classification of exporters/canalisation through STC for ore exports as reasonable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Glass Chatons Importers & Users Association v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Canalisation through STC valid under identical cl.6(h); reasonable in public interest, no Art 19/31 violation.

statutes_cited.name: Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers prohibition/restriction/canalisation of exports; fee only for licence applications.

statutes_cited.name: Export Control Order, 1968
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits export without licence; allows refusal for canalisation through specialised agencies.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No violation by canalisation scheme, date fixation, service charge.

outcome.summary: The Court upheld the validity of the impugned Trade Notices canalising mica exports through the Corporation, rejected all constitutional challenges under Articles 14, 19(1)(g), 265, found scheme reasonable and non-discriminatory, service charge valid, relaxations bona fide. Petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "The canalisation of export through the Corporation would ensure a uniform good quality of goods and also increase the volume of export."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key rationale upholding scheme as reasonable restriction.

key_quotes.text: "If the Government decides an economic policy that import or export should be by a selected channel or through selected agencies the court would proceed on the assumption that the decision is in the interest of the general public unless the contrary is shown."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Glass Chatons; presumption of validity for canalisation.

key_quotes.text: "The service charges are nothing but quid pro quo for the services rendered by the Corporation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
